title: Gene expression state space models and cell fate transitions

author: John Quackenbush, Department of Biostatistics, Harvard University

summarization_data.sent: A lot of what I'm going to do is tell you about some ideas that have, really, I think, come to fruition with work they've been doing during the past summer, working in collaboration with just Mar, who's a postdoctoral fellow with me and Christine Wells at the Sky to Stem Cell Institute in Brisbane.
So actually spend a very balmy winter in Brisbane over the last three months.
And a lot of it really was work.
That sort of grew out of some ideas that we've been kicking around for awhile and actually work.

That just started doing as part of her PhD thesis an my group, and I've been thinking about modeling for a long time, and some of the work we've done is actually Bayesian network based modeling that was similar to what you heard about earlier, and it really has think about what we mean by models, and in fact, if you talk to people who are involved in models, use it modeling you see.

A wide range of different approaches from people who write very complex sets of coupled differential equations and try to estimate many many parameters to people who try to build models that are much more empirical, and we can define the side of being people, build empirical models or phenomenological models and my background.
My training in fact was in theoretical physics, not in biology, and as I started to do physics in physics, there are there's definitely theory, and there's definitely experiment.
But sitting right between them is this branch of physics called phenomenology and phenomenology is really focused on the idea that you have to build in.
